citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee continues to not provide the attending veterinarian (AV) appropriate authority over the veterinary care of the
animals at the facility.
** According to medical records, George, a male 5-year-old, French Bulldog microchip #992001000364968 was
diagnosed heartworm positive on March 21, 2023. As part of his medical treatment plan, the attending veterinarian
instructed the licensee to restrict George’s activity. George was first observed as not activity restricted at the time of the
previous inspection, April 3rd, 2023. Today, a smaller pen was evident within the larger dog run which, according to the
licensee, was built to contain the dog and restrict activity. However, at the time of inspection George was found outside of
the restricted area; he was found running with his enclosure mate in the larger 10 ft. x 23 ft dog run and not activity
restricted as the attending veterinarian had instructed.
** A black and white, male, approximately 12-week-old kitten, “Gerschwind” was seen by the attending veterinarian on
April 4, 2023 for and upper respiratory infection and put on treatment. During the inspection he was identified as having
worsened over the last couple of days. The attending veterinarian was unaware of the worsening condition and confirmed
with inspectors that the licensee had failed to bring “Gerschwind” in for his re-check appointment that was instructed by
the attending veterinarian for four days after his initial veterinary visit to ensure the animal was improving with treatment.
Failure to ensure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority over the veterinary care of the animals can lead
to unnecessary pain and suffering of the animals. Correct by ensuring the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority
over the veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two animals with identified health concerns were never conveyed to the attending veterinarian for evaluation.
** A black and white, male, approximately 8-week-old kitten, “Gerschwind” was finishing treatment prescribed by the
attending veterinarian for an upper respiratory infection on April 4, 2023. On inspection, he was constantly squinting and
the third eyelid was partially covering each eye. The tissues around both eyes are swollen, bright pink, and inflamed with
pale discharge wetting and crusting the fur. According to the licensee, his eyes were improving on treatment but then
worsened over the last couple of days. The licensee had not notified the attending veterinarian of the kitten’s worsening
eye condition.
** During the last inspection on April 3, 2023, an 8-year-old adult female white long-haired cat #900215000825306 was
found with foul breath and had severely reddened and swollen gums at the upper and lower jaws and especially towards
the back of the mouth. The cat exhibited pain and sensitivity of the gums by retracting its head when the gums were
palpated. The last inspection report instructed that the attending veterinarian be notified of this animal’s condition so that
appropriate treatment could be determined and followed. At today’s inspection, the licensee reported that this cat was
adopted out to a to a new owner on April 9, 2023, and no veterinary care was sought prior to it leaving the facility nor was
the attending veterinarian notified of its dental condition.
Failure to communicate health concerns or problems to the attending veterinarian can lead to unnecessary prolonged
suffering of an animal and cause more severe medical conditions as diseases/injuries progress.
Correct by ensuring that daily observation is performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is established so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

The primary dog enclosures do not contain the animals securely. Upon entrance to the facility, one adult female French
bulldog with a cream and white coat was observed running around the yard, outside of her primary enclosure which she
had escaped. After being replaced into her enclosure by the licensee, the dog managed to escape once more during the
inspection and was again found running freely in the main yard surrounded only by the perimeter fence.
Animals that are able to escape their primary enclosures can become seriously injured, lost, or end up in another
enclosure with an incompatible animal. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures for dogs and cats are constructed
and maintained so that they contain the dogs and cats securely.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Rachel Perez-Baum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee continues to not provide the attending veterinarian (AV) appropriate authority over the veterinary care of the

** A black and white, male, approximately 12-week-old kitten, “Gerschwind” was seen by the attending veterinarian on

2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two animals with identified health concerns were never conveyed to the attending veterinarian for evaluation.  
 
** A black and white, male, approximately 8-week-old kitten, “Gerschwind” was finishing treatment prescribed by the

Failure to communicate health concerns or problems to the attending veterinarian can lead to unnecessary prolonged

Correct by ensuring that daily observation is performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a

3.6(a)(2)(iii)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary dog enclosures do not contain the animals securely. Upon entrance to the facility, one adult female French 
bulldog with a cream and white coat was observed running around the yard, outside of her primary enclosure which she 
had escaped. After being replaced into her enclosure by the licensee, the dog managed to escape once more during the

Animals that are able to escape their primary enclosures can become seriously injured, lost, or end up in another 
enclosure with an incompatible animal. Correct by ensuring that all primary enclosures for dogs and cats are constructed 
and maintained so that they contain the dogs and cats securely. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
Rachel Perez-Baum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
